item.description:
"He's like a house with locked doors. All he has done is within him, like a gentle music perhaps - but who can hear it?" — from Five Women

Robert Musil (1880-1942), a central figure in the modernist movement, is known primarily for his magnum opus, The Man Without Qualities. But here, in these five stories stories as crucial to the understanding of that book—and Musil's immense literary influence and significance—as Joyce's Dubliners is to Ulysses, he displays another face, one that is by turn extravagant, sensual, mystical, and autobiographical.

"Intensely sensual and thick with eroticism, these beautifully written stories ultimately resist reduction. Their true concern is erotic love itself, not its object." —The New York Times

"In his descriptions of love affairs and especially in the portraits of women in love, Musil is truly original; in managing scenes of physical love, he has not been approached by any writer of the last fifty years." — V.S. Pritchett

Please read and come prepared to discuss:

Tonka

Grigia

The Perfecting of a Love

group.name: Classic Books: Book Club for Die-hard Readers

item.name: Musil: Five Women
